titleproper.value:
Guide to the Louis Torres Federal Hall Research Notes
                    <lb/>circa 1960
                    <lb/>
                    <num>MS 3028</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Larry Weimer

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2017-05-26T10:16-0400</date>

unittitle.value: Louis Torres Federal Hall research notes

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: The collection includes National Park Service historian Louis Torres's (1921-2017) research notes from the late 1950s to early 1960s concerning the history of the building site now known as the Federal Hall National Memorial. The bulk of the collection includes about 700 index cards identifying sources of information and a small number of photographs and other documents.

p.value: Open to qualified researchers. Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)
This collection should be cited as the Louis Torres Federal Hall Research Notes, MS 3028, The New-York Historical Society.
Gift of Louis Torres's daughter, Patricia Cronenberger.

(Principal sources for the above note are the National Park Service's newsletter 
                <emph render="italic">Courier</emph>, 
                <extref ns2:actuate="onRequest" ns2:href="http://npshistory.com/newsletters/courier/courier-v4n3.pdf">Vol. 4, No. 3</extref> of March 1981 and the 
                <extref ns2:actuate="onRequest" ns2:href="http://www.mhsarchive.org/FullImages/FEHA1925-NPS-Administrative-Records.pdf">finding aid</extref> for the administrative records of the Federal Hall National Memorial.)

There is also one folder with a small number of other documents including miscellaneous correspondence with James Heslin, Director of the New-York Historical Society, Professor James Grote Van Derpool of Columbia University, and Joan (Reilly?) regarding sale of Old City Hall; photographic prints and negatives; and part of a manuscript on “History of Rahway” with a particular focus on John Frazee.

corpname.value: Federal Hall National Memorial (New York, N.Y.).
